tit.e: Suzakumon (the Main, Southern Gate of the Palace City)
tit.cmt: eliminated description in parenthesis since it is described directly below; added "Gate" to be more consistent with other articles translated into English

sen.j: 朱雀門（すざくもん）は、古代、平城京や平安京といった条坊制の宮城（大内裏）において南面する正門。
sen.e: Suzakumon was the southern front gate of an ancient Emperor's residence (called daidairi) such as Heijo-kyo and Heian-Kyo whose layout looked like a massive chessboard.

Suzakumon Gate was the main gate built on the southern end of imperial palaces (called daidairi) in ancient Japanese cities, such as Heijo-kyo (capital of Japan in Nara from 710 to 740 and from 745 to 784) and Heian-kyo (capital of Japan in Kyoto from 794 to 1868) that had grid-patterned city layouts.
sen.cmt: changed "front" to "main" for "正門"; changed "Emperor's residence" to "imperial palaces" for "宮城"; added description for "Heijo-Kyo" and "Heian-Kyo" from each of the English wiki articles, respectively; changed "massive chessboard" to "grid-patterned"; fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: Suzakumon Gate was the main gate built on the southern end of Imperial Palaces (called daidairi) in ancient Japanese cities, such as Heijo-kyo (capital of Japan in Nara from 710 to 740 and from 745 to 784) and Heian-kyo (capital of Japan in Kyoto from 794 to 1868) that had grid-patterned city layouts.
sen.cmt: Imperial Palacesに訂正しました。

sen.j: 宮城の12の門のうち最も重要な門であった。
sen.e: It was the most important of all 12 residential gates.
Out of the twelve palace gates, Suzakumon was the most important.

sen.j: 中国の条坊制を模範に造営された古代都城では、中央北辺に宮殿、官衙からなる宮城が置かれた。
sen.e: In an ancient capital established based on a Chinese chessboard like city structure, an Emperor's residence consisting of a palace and kanga (government office) was placed in the northern central part of the city.

In ancient capitals that were established in accordance with the Chinese grid-patterned city layout, imperial palaces, consisting of a palace and a kanga (government office), were placed in the northern central part of the city.
sen.cmt: made "capital" plural; changed "Emperor's residence" to "Imperial Palace" for "宮城"; fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: In ancient capitals that were established in accordance with the Chinese grid-patterned city layout, Imperial Palaces, consisting of a palace and a kanga (government office), were placed in the northern central part of the city.
sen.cmt: Imperial Palacesに訂正しました。

sen.j: 平城京では平城宮、平安京では大内裏などといい、大内裏とも呼ばれた。
sen.e: The residence was also called Heijo-kyu Palace in Heijo-Kyo and daidairi in Heian-Kyo, but was called daidairi in general.
The palace was given such names as Heijo-kyu Palace in Heijo-kyo but was generally referred to as daidairi as it was in Heian-kyo.
sen.cmt: changed "residence" to "palace" for consistency; changed structure so that "daidairi" needed to be mentioned only once
sen.e: The palace was given such names as Heijo-kyu Palace in Heijo-kyo but was generally referred to as daidairi as it was in Heian-kyo.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 大内裏には四方に12の門が備えられ、各々有力氏族の姓が付与されていた。
sen.e: Daidairi had 12 gates on four sides, and each gate had the family name of a powerful clan.
The daidairi had twelve gates on four sides, each gate having the family name of a powerful clan.

sen.j: 南門は「天子南面す」というように、皇宮より京師を睥睨（へいげい）する最も重要な門であった。
sen.e: As the saying 'people of high ranks see the south' suggests, the south gate was the most important gate through which the keishi (capital) was observed from the Imperial Palace.

sen.e: The gate was also called 'Otomomon' given the name of the Otomo clan, which was a powerful clan in the Imperial Court.

sen.j: 714年（和銅7年）これを漢風に改め、四神において南方を守護するとされる朱雀の名を冠したものとした。
sen.e: In 714, the gate system was revised to adopt the Chinese way, and the south gate was given the name Suzaku (Vermilion Bird, a god said to rule over the southern heavens), which was one of the shijin (four gods said to rule over the four directions) that was believed to protect the south.
sen.cmt: 朱雀「すじゃく」「しゅじゃく」とも読むようです。
sen.e: In 714, the gate system was revised into the Chinese style with the south gate being named Suzaku (a Vermilion Bird and a god said to rule over the southern heavens), which was one of the shijin (four gods said to rule over the four directions) that was believed to protect the south.

sen.j: 朱雀門から都城正門の羅城門に続く大路を朱雀大路という。
sen.e: A wide street that led from Suzaku gate to rasho gate, or the front gate of the capital city, was called Suzaku-oji Street.
The wide street leading from Suzakumon Gate to Rashomon Gate, the front gate of the capital city, was called Suzaku-oji Street.

sen.j: 長岡京や平安京でも同じ名を冠した門を宮城正門とした。
sen.e: In both Nagaoka-Kyo and Heian-Kyo, the gate given the same name was the front gate for the Emperor's residence and was considered to be one of the most important gates along with Oten-mon gate which was the front gate of Chodo-in, or the state chamber of the Imperial Court.

It was considered to be one of the most important gates, along with Otenmon Gate positioned in front of the Chodo-in, the state chamber of the Imperial Court.

sen.j: しかし、大内裏の衰微に従い次第に荒廃し、ついには鬼や盗賊が住むといわれるほどに荒れ果てたという。
sen.e: The area around the gate however gradually fell into ruin as the power of daidairi declined, and at the end, it was so rundown that oni (ogres) or thieves were believed to live in that area.

sen.j: 平安宮朱雀門は現在の京都市二条千本通にあったといい、旧跡には小さな石碑が立つのみである。

sen.j: 平城宮の朱雀門は1997年、考古学的研究と奈良県下の寺社に残る門を参考にして、五間三戸の二重門がかつての位置に等寸復元されている（平城宮跡）。
sen.e: The life-size goken sanko (a gate in which the three central spaces out of five created by columns were used as entrances) Suzaku gate of the Heijo-Kyu Palace, having a two-story structure and double roofs, was restored in 1997 based on findings in archeological studies and gates remaining in temples in Nara prefecture (Heijo-Kyu Palace ruin).

Suzakumon Gate of the Heijo-Kyu Palace was restored in 1997 with a two-story structure, double roofs and a life-sized goken sanko (a gate where three of the five spaces between its columns are used as entrances). The restorations were based on gates that remain in temples in Nara prefecture (Heijo-Kyu palace ruin) and findings in archeological studies.
